Cell-Free Massive MIMO
for Wireless Federated Learning

Abstract

This paper proposes a novel scheme for cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (CFmMIMO) networks to support any federated learning (FL) framework. This scheme allows each instead of all the iterations of the FL framework to happen in a large-scale coherence time to guarantee a stable operation of an FL process. To show how to optimize the FL performance using this proposed scheme, we consider an existing FL framework as an example and target FL training time minimization for this framework. An optimization problem is then formulated to jointly optimize the local accuracy, transmit power, data rate, and usersâ€™ processing frequency. This mixed-timescale stochastic nonconvex problem captures the complex interactions among the training time, and transmission and computation of training updates of one FL process. By employing the online successive convex approximation approach, we develop a new algorithm to solve the formulated problem with proven convergence to the neighbourhood of its stationary points. Our numerical results confirm that the presented joint design reduces the training time by up to 55%percent5555\% over baseline approaches. They also show that CFmMIMO here requires the lowest training time for FL processes compared with cell-free time-division multiple access massive MIMO and collocated massive MIMO.

Index Terms:
Cell-free massive MIMO, federated learning.

I Introduction

The use of machine learning (ML) techniques in telecommunications industry has been growing dramatically in recent years [1, 2]. One reason for this trend is the fast growing number of mobile devices, wearable devices and autonomous vehicles. They are generating a vast amount of data by using in-built sensors, e.g., microphones, GPS and camera, for critical applications such as traffic navigation, indoor localization, image recognition, natural language processing, and augmented reality [3]. In addition, the computational capabilities of these devices also grow significantly with dedicated hardware architecture and computing engines, e.g., the energy-efficient Qualcomm Hexagon Vector eXtensions on Snapdragon 835835835 [4]. On-device artificial intelligence (AI) capabilities are predicted to be available on 80%percent8080\% of all smartphones by 202220222022 [5]. It is therefore critical for telecommunications operators to start investigating into a future communications system that efficiently utilizes the empowered computation resources from mobile devices to solve ML problems.

The typical ML framework used in the current telecommunications systems requires a cloud center to store and process raw data collected by the user equipment (UEs). However, such a centralized structure fails to support real-time applications because of its high latency [6]. The concept of mobile edge computing is introduced to process data at the edge nodes instead of the cloud center [7, 8]. Since the computational capability of mobile devices is growing noticeably, it is possible to even push the network computation further to the mobile device level [9, 10]. On the other hand, serious concerns about data privacy have recently been raised due to data being processed by third-party companies, e.g., Facebook, Apple. This urgently calls for a new class of ML frameworks that not only exploit the computational resources of the UEs for ML applications but also ensure data privacy.

A promising candidate for such ML frameworks is the recently developed Federated Learning (FL) [9, 11]. As shown in Fig.Â 1, an FL process is an iterative process in which the UEs use their local training data to compute local model training updates, followed by sending the updates to a central server. The central server then aggregates these updates to compute the global training update, which is then sent back to the UEs to further assist their local update computation. This iterative process terminates when a certain learning accuracy level is attained. Data privacy is protected by not sharing the local training data, but only the local training updates computed at the UEs using local computational resources. Uploading only the local training updates to the central server incurs a significantly lower delay, compared to uploading a large amount of raw data. This distributed approach facilitates a large-scale model training and more flexible data collection, albeit at the expense of UEsâ€™ computational resources [10].

With all the promising advantages listed above, FL has attracted much attention from both developer and researcher communities [12, 13, 14, 15, 10, 16, 17]. In [12], an FL algorithm for keyboard prediction on smartphones is developed by Google. [13] target improving the performance of the general FL algorithms, while [14, 15, 16, 10, 17] concentrate on optimizing the performance of FL algorithms used in wireless networks. In particular, [13] proposes a new compression framework for a communication-efficient FL system. [10] aims to obtain the best trade-off between FL training time and UE energy consumption. [14] proposes an incentive mechanism that encourages the UEs with high-quality data to participate in FL systems. [15] introduces a control algorithm to achieve the best trade-off between the number of local updates and that of global updates for a given resource budget. A joint device selection and beamforming design is proposed in [16] to enhance the performance of FL. [17] proposes a joint design of user selection, power control and subchannel allocation for minimizing the loss function of FL.

This paper investigates how to implement FL in a wireless network. It is worth noting that the existing works [10, 16] rely on an impractical assumption that the channel state information (CSI) remains unchanged during the whole FL process. In practice however, the channel changes in the order of milliseconds; and as such, certain system parameters for FL performance optimization, e.g., data rates and power control, would have become obsolete even before the FL process terminates. In addition, it might not be most efficient to use orthogonal multiplexing approaches, e.g., orthogonal frequency-division multiple access (OFDMA) [17] and time-division multiple access (TDMA) [10], for UEs to transmit their local updates. With a large number of UEs, the total training time could be significantly prolonged. To both deal with the wireless channel dynamics and to serve UEs at the same time and in the same frequency bands, a new wireless network structure that supports FL is called for.

In this work, we propose using cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (CFmMIMO) [18, 19] for FL in a wireless environment. Here, a central processing unit (CPU) (i.e., the central server) is connected to a large number of access point (APs) via backhaul links. These APs then simultaneously serve UEs via wireless links using the same frequency bands with the CSI acquired via uplink (UL) training pilots. An important characteristic of massive MIMO is channel hardening [20], i.e., the effective channel gain at the UEs is close to its expected valueâ€”a known deterministic constant [19]. As such, the channels are reasonably stable during one large-scale coherence time T~csubscript~ğ‘‡ğ‘\widetilde{T}_{c}111During one large-scale coherence time T~csubscript~ğ‘‡ğ‘\widetilde{T}_{c}, the large-scale fading coefficients are reasonably invariant. The value of T~csubscript~ğ‘‡ğ‘\widetilde{T}_{c} can be empirically measured, in the same way for small-scale fading measurement. For indoor communications, the large-scale coherence time can be at least 404040 small-scale fading coherence time [19], and it has a time order of seconds.. The channel dynamics due to small-scale fading thus have negligible effects on the FL processes. In addition, a CFmMIMO network also provides a high probability of coverage, making the FL processes less prone to the unfavorable UE links.

Our research contributions are summarized as follows.

  • â€¢

    We propose, for the first time, a scheme for CFmMIMO networks to support any FL framework. In this scheme, any iterative algorithm can be developed to optimize the FL performance before the FL process is executed. Each instead of all iterations of this FL optimization algorithm or the FL process happens within one T~csubscript~ğ‘‡ğ‘\widetilde{T}_{c} in order to guarantee channel stability during its operation. In each iteration of the FL process, we propose using the APs as relays to transmit the training updates between the CPU and UEs. Doing so allows any beamforming/filtering design to be applied to the APs in order to enhance the performance of training update transmission.

  • â€¢

    To show how to optimize the FL performance using the proposed scheme, we consider an existing FL framework [21] as an example and target the key performance metric of â€œtraining time minimizationâ€. We formulate a mixed-timescale stochastic nonconvex optimization problem that minimizes the time of one FL process. The formulated problem captures the complex interactions among the FL training time, and transmission and computation of FL training updates in a CFmMIMO network. Here, a conjugate beamforming/matched filtering scheme is applied to the APs for ease of implementation. The local accuracy, power control, data rate and UEâ€™s processing frequency are jointly designed, subject to the practical constraints on UEsâ€™ energy consumption and imperfect channel estimation.

  • â€¢

    Utilizing the general framework in [22], we propose a new algorithm that is proven to converge to at least the neighborhood of the stationary points of the formulated problem. Here, the coupling among the variables makes it challenging to develop a specific algorithm that satisfies all the strict conditions stated in the general framework of [22]. It is also noted that our algorithm only requires channel stability in each but not all iterations. This important feature ensures the problem and its solution remain up-to-date and valid during the running time of the algorithm, despite the channel variations.

  • â€¢

    Simulation results verify the convergence of the proposed algorithm, and show that our solution reduces the training time by up to 55%percent5555\% compared with the baseline schemes. They further confirm that CFmMIMO offers the lowest training time compared to cell-free TDMA massive MIMO and collocated massive MIMO.

Paper Organization and Notation: The rest of this paper is organized as follows. SectionÂ II proposes a novel scheme for a CFmMIMO network to support a general FL framework. SectionÂ III introduces a specific example of the general FL framework considered in this paper. SectionÂ IV presents the system model and assumptions. SectionÂ V formulates the FL training time minimization problem, whereas SectionÂ VI proposes a new algorithm to solve the formulated problem. For comparison, SectionÂ VII introduces cell-free TDMA and collocated massive MIMO systems to also support the considered FL framework. SectionÂ VIII verifies the performance of the developed algorithm through comprehensive numerical examples. Finally, SectionÂ IX concludes the paper.

II Proposed Scheme for CFmMIMO Networks to Support FL

II-A The General FL Framework

A global ML problem is solved at a central server with a global training data set partitioned over a number of participating clients. Each client trains their local model by an arbitrary learning algorithm. Let ğ’¦={1,â€¦,K}ğ’¦1â€¦ğ¾\operatorname{\mathcal{K}}=\{1,...,K\} be the set of clients and Dksubscriptğ·ğ‘˜D_{k} the size of the local data stored at client kğ‘˜k. In a typical supervised learning, a data sample iâˆˆğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ’Ÿi\in\operatorname{\mathcal{D}} is defined as an input-output pair {ğ±iâˆˆâ„d,yi}subscriptğ±ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\{\operatorname{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},y_{i}\}.

In a general FL framework to solve the general ML problem (1), this problem is decomposed into Kğ¾K separate local ML problems that are solved at Kğ¾K clients in parallel. For ease of presentation, we make the following definitions.

Definition 1.

â€œGlobal DL training updateâ€ is the information sent from the central server to the clients. Similarly, â€œglobal UL training updatesâ€ are those from the clients to the central server.

The general FL framework is described in AlgorithmÂ 1. Each iteration of AlgorithmÂ 1 consists the four key steps (S1)-(S4).

Definition 2.

â€œAn FL processâ€ is defined as a full execution of AlgorithmÂ 1.

Remark 1.

The designs of local ML problems at the clients, the global DL/UL training updates, and the types of aggregation of training updates at the central server are different according to the different designs of FL frameworks for different types of objective functions due to different ML applications [23, 24, 25, 26, 21, 27].

II-B Proposed Cell-Free Massive MIMO Network Structure to Support the General FL Framework

Here, we propose using the CFmMIMO network structure [19] illustrated in Fig.Â 1 to support the general FL framework discussed above. In this structure, a central processing unit (CPU) is connected to a set of access points (APs) â„³={1,â€¦,M}â„³1â€¦ğ‘€\operatorname{\mathcal{M}}=\{1,...,M\} via backhaul links with sufficient capacities. These APs serve a given set ğ’¦ğ’¦\operatorname{\mathcal{K}} of participating UEs via wireless access links at the same time and in the same frequency bands222In general, since the UEs are geographically distributed, some user may loss the connectivity, and hence, cannot participate in the FL process. However, one of the main strong property of CFmMIMO is that, with very high probability, it can provide uniformly good service for all users in the networks [19]. In the other words, in CFmMIMO, the connectivity probability of each user is very high. Therefore, in the paper, for simplicity, we assume that all UEs participate in the FL process.. The APs and UEs are each equipped with a single antenna. The CPU and UEs act as the central server and the clients in the general FL framework, respectively. The APs are used to relay the training updates between the CPU and the UEs

Remark 2.

Both the AP and UEs can be considered as the clients in the general FL framework. In this paper, we choose the UEs to be the clients instead of the APs [10]. By doing so, data privacy is more protected since raw data does not have to be shared over wireless networks. Moreover, the computational resource of the UEs can be empowered with new computing engines such as Snapdragon 835835835 [4]. It is possible to push the ML tasks further to the UEs [9, 10].

II-C Proposed Scheme for a CFmMIMO to Support the General FL framework

Now, to realize an FL process in the considered CFmMIMO network structure, we propose a general scheme shown in Fig.Â 3. As seen from the figure, we divide the time period during which the statistics of large-scale fading is stable into multiple time intervals. The first interval of â€œFL performance optimizationâ€ is used for optimizing the performance of FL. The remaining intervals are reserved for the FL process; hence, termed as â€œFL processâ€ intervals.

II-C1 Optimizing the performance of FL

In the â€œFL performance optimizationâ€ interval, any algorithms can be developed to optimize the performance of FL before the FL processes are executed. Here, we denote by â€œsystem parametersâ€ the parameters that are designed by the FL optimization algorithm. These parameters are grouped into short-term and long-term parameters. The short-term parameters change in the timescale of large-scale coherence times, whereas the long-term parameters the statistics of large-scale fading. In each iteration of the optimization algorithm, the short-term parameters are designed in the short-term optimization (STO) time blocks, whereas the long-term parameters in the long-term optimization (LTO) time blocks. As a result of the channel hardening effect in massive MIMO, the wireless channel remains unchanged during one large-scale coherence time T~csubscript~ğ‘‡ğ‘\widetilde{T}_{c}. In practice, the completion time of the optimization algorithm can be larger than T~csubscript~ğ‘‡ğ‘\widetilde{T}_{c}. Therefore, we insist that only one iteration of the algorithm is to happen within T~csubscript~ğ‘‡ğ‘\widetilde{T}_{c}.

II-C2 Implementing the FL process

In the â€œFL processâ€ intervals, the FL process is executed with the long-term parameters obtained from the â€œFL performance optimizationâ€ interval. The short-term parameters are optimized in the STO time block to enhance the performance of training update transmission before each iteration of the FL process. Since the completion time of the FL process can be larger than T~csubscript~ğ‘‡ğ‘\widetilde{T}_{c}, we insist that both STO and â€œone iteration of the FL processâ€ time blocks are to happen in one T~csubscript~ğ‘‡ğ‘\widetilde{T}_{c}. Here, we note that the results of the LTO time blocks remain unchanged for several FL process, while the results of the STO time blocks are invariant only in one iteration of an FL process. Therefore, after the â€œFL performance optimizationâ€ step is executed, only the results of the LTO time block are used in FL processes. In each iteration of an FL process, the results of the STO time block are not the results of the STO time block in the â€œFL performance optimizationâ€ step, but rather are computed by the same method used for the STO time block in the â€œFL performance optimizationâ€ step.

II-C3 Implementing each iteration of the FL process

Fig.Â 3 shows the time block of â€œone iteration of the FL processâ€, in which the intervals of the four key steps (S1)-(S4) to implement each iteration of the FL process by the CFmMIMO network model are illustrated. Here, the interval of Step (S1) in AlgorithmÂ 1 consists one interval of â€œDL training update transmission (DLTUT) via backhaul linksâ€ from the CPU to the APs, and one interval of â€œDLTUT via wireless linksâ€ from the APs to the UEs. The interval of Step (S3) includes one interval of â€œUL training udpate transmission (ULTUT) via wireless linksâ€ from the UEs to the APs, and one interval of â€œULTUT via backhaul linksâ€ from the APs to the CPU.

As also seen from Fig.Â 3, we split each time block of â€œDLTUT via wireless linksâ€ or â€œULTUT via wireless linksâ€ into multiple intervals. The intervals of â€œUL trainingâ€ is used for channel estimation. The remaining intervals are used for DL/UL training update transmission333The proposed scheme above focuses only on support FL. Therefore, in each small-scale coherence time, all the times not used to estimate the channel are used for transmitting training updates. The scheme that supports FL and data transmission at the same time is left for future works.. In these â€œDLTUTâ€ or â€œULTUTâ€ intervals, any beamforming/filtering design can be applied to optimize the performance of training update transmission. Here, we insist that the pair of â€œUL trainingâ€ and â€œDLTUTâ€/â€œULTUTâ€ intervals happen in one small-scale coherence time Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c} in order to adapt to the variation of small-scale fading444In this work, we consider time-division duplexing (TDD) where channels are first estimated at the APs via uplink channel estimation. Owing to the channel reciprocity property in massive MIMO, these channel estimates will then be used for: (i) precoding the data symbols in the downlink data transmission, and (ii) used for combining the received signals in the uplink data transmission. Moreover, there is no need for downlink channel estimation because of the channel hardening property in massive MIMO systems. This transmission protocol is widely used in the massive MIMO literature (see, e.g., [28]).. In addition, the data size of training updates may be larger than the amount of data that can be transmitted in Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c}. As such, there may be one or several â€œDLTUTâ€ or â€œULTUTâ€ intervals in each â€œDLTUT via wireless linksâ€ or â€œULTUT via wireless linksâ€ time block in order to complete the transmission of one global DL/UL training update.

Remark 3.

The proposed CFmMIMO network model in SectionÂ II-B and the proposed scheme in SectionÂ II-C can be used to support any version of the general FL framework to solve any global ML problem. This scheme only requires developing specific algorithms to optimize the performance of specific FL frameworks. In the following, we consider a specific example of the general FL framework and investigate an algorithm to optimize the FL performance of this framework.

III A Specific Example of the General FL Framework

Given the proposed framework in Section II, this section considers a specific example of the general FL framework to show how the performance of an FL process can be optimized in the latter sections. In particular, the FL optimization problem for this example is introduced in SectionÂ V, and the algorithms to solve this problem are proposed in SectionÂ VI.

Because of all the potential advantages offered by FL, many versions [23, 24, 25, 26, 21, 27] of the general FL framework have so far been studied despite research on FL is still in its infancy. Here, we consider an existing FL framework of [21] which is briefly introduced as follows. In this FL framework, the considered loss function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is convex and the dual problem of (1) is written as

is the quadratic approximation of JD~subscriptğ½~ğ·J_{\widetilde{D}} at the dual variable (ğœ¶[k]+Ï•[k])subscriptğœ¶delimited-[]ğ‘˜subscriptbold-italic-Ï•delimited-[]ğ‘˜(\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}_{[k]}+\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\phi}}_{[k]}). Here, the only information shared between the clients and the central server is the change in ğŒğŒ\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\chi}}.

At iteration nğ‘›n, each client kâˆˆğ’¦ğ‘˜ğ’¦k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{K}} solves (3) by an arbitrary iterative algorithm with a local accuracy level of Î¸ğœƒ\theta in order to obtain its optimal solution Ï•[k]âˆ—superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•delimited-[]ğ‘˜\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\phi}}_{[k]}^{*}. The local dual variable is updated as

ğœ¶[k](n+1)=ğœ¶[k](n)+Ï•[k]âˆ—.superscriptsubscriptğœ¶delimited-[]ğ‘˜ğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğœ¶delimited-[]ğ‘˜ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•delimited-[]ğ‘˜\displaystyle\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}_{[k]}^{(n+1)}=\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}_{[k]}^{(n)}+\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\phi}}_{[k]}^{*}. (5)

Each client kâˆˆğ’¦ğ‘˜ğ’¦k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{K}} then shares its local change in ğŒ(n)superscriptğŒğ‘›\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\chi}}^{(n)}, i.e.,

Î”â€‹ğŒk(n)=1Î»â€‹D~â€‹ğ—[k]â¡Ï•[k]âˆ—,Î”superscriptsubscriptğŒğ‘˜ğ‘›1ğœ†~ğ·subscriptğ—delimited-[]ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•delimited-[]ğ‘˜\displaystyle\Delta\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\chi}}_{k}^{(n)}=\tfrac{1}{\lambda\widetilde{D}}\operatorname{\boldsymbol{X}}_{[k]}\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\phi}}_{[k]}^{*}, (6)

to the central server. The central server aggregates the local information Î”â€‹ğŒk(n)Î”superscriptsubscriptğŒğ‘˜ğ‘›\Delta\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\chi}}_{k}^{(n)} received from all the clients and updates ğŒğŒ\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\chi}} as

ğŒ(n+1)=ğŒ(n)+1Kâ€‹Î”â€‹ğŒk(n).superscriptğŒğ‘›1superscriptğŒğ‘›1ğ¾Î”superscriptsubscriptğŒğ‘˜ğ‘›\displaystyle\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\chi}}^{(n+1)}=\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\chi}}^{(n)}+\tfrac{1}{K}\Delta\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\chi}}_{k}^{(n)}. (7)

ğŒ(n+1)superscriptğŒğ‘›1\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\chi}}^{(n+1)} is finally sent back to the clients to solve (3). This process will terminate when a global accuracy level of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is reached. The FL framework described above is summarized in AlgorithmÂ 2. Each iteration of AlgorithmÂ 2 also consists of four key steps (S1)-(S4) as that of AlgorithmÂ 1.

We assume that each client kâˆˆğ’¦ğ‘˜ğ’¦k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{K}} uses optimization algorithms such as stochastic average gradient (SAG) and stochastic variance reduced gradient (SVRG) to solve (3) with a local accuracy level of Î¸ğœƒ\theta. The number of local iterations is then [26]

Lâ€‹(Î¸)=Î½â€‹logâ¡(1Î¸),ğ¿ğœƒğœˆ1ğœƒ\displaystyle L(\theta)=\nu\log(\tfrac{1}{\theta}), (8)

where Î½>0ğœˆ0\nu>0 depends on the data size and structure of the local problem [26]. On the other hand, for strongly convex objective functions and the global accuracy level of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, the number of global iterations are given by [21]

Gâ€‹(Î¸)=Ï‘â€‹logâ¡(1Ïµ)1âˆ’Î¸,ğºğœƒitalic-Ï‘1italic-Ïµ1ğœƒ\displaystyle G(\theta)=\frac{\vartheta\log\left(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right)}{1-\theta}, (9)

where Ï‘>0italic-Ï‘0\vartheta>0 is a factor that depends on the characteristic and size of the whole data set [21, Theorem 4.2]. Here, we assume that the characteristic and size of the whole data set does not change over the FL processes. Therefore, Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta is constant and known [10].

Remark 4.

In more complex ML models such as deep neural networks, the loss function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is usually non-convex. Therefore, instead of the framework in [21], more advanced FL frameworks are needed. In this paper, we choose to consider the FL framework in [21] for simpler ML models because it provides a clear relationship (9) between the number of global training updates and the local accuracy for ease of optimizing FL performance (see the next sections). Such a clear relationship is hard to find in the advanced FL frameworks with non-convex loss functions.

IV Detailed System Model to Support FL

This section details the CFmMIMO system model used to support the transmission and computation of the training updates in each iteration of the FL process (see Fig.Â 3).

IV-A Steps (S1) and (S3) in Each Iteration of the FL Process: Model of Training Update Transmission

Remark 5.

In indoor communications, the time for UL training can be much smaller than the small-scale coherence time Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c}. Suppose Ï„t=20subscriptğœğ‘¡20\tau_{t}=20, the time for UL channel estimation is tcâ€‹e=Ï„tBc=0.02â€‹msâ‰ªTcsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘’subscriptğœğ‘¡subscriptğµğ‘0.02msmuch-less-thansubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘t_{ce}=\frac{\tau_{t}}{B_{c}}=0.02~{}\text{ms}\ll T_{c}. IV-B Step (S2) in Each Iteration of the FL Process: Model of Local Training Update Computation at UEs

Denote by cksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜c_{k} (cycles/sample) the number of processing cycles for a UE kğ‘˜k to process one data sample. cksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜c_{k} is known a priori by an offline measurement [30]. Let Dksubscriptğ·ğ‘˜D_{k} (samples) and fksubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜f_{k} (cycles/s) be the size of the local data set and the processing frequency of the UE kğ‘˜k, respectively. The latency of computing the local training update at the UE kğ‘˜k is by

tC,kâ€‹(Î¸,fk)=Lâ€‹(Î¸)â€‹Dkâ€‹ckfk,subscriptğ‘¡ğ¶ğ‘˜ğœƒsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ¿ğœƒsubscriptğ·ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜\displaystyle t_{C,k}(\theta,f_{k})=L(\theta)\frac{D_{k}c_{k}}{f_{k}}, (22)

where Lâ€‹(Î¸)ğ¿ğœƒL(\theta) is the number of local training iterations (see (8)) and Dkâ€‹ckfksubscriptğ·ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜\frac{D_{k}c_{k}}{f_{k}} is the time taken to compute the local update over its local training data set in each iteration. Given the limited computational resource at the UEs, we only focus on the delay of computing the local updates at the UEs. Since the computational resource of the CPU is much more abundant than that of the UEs, the latency of aggregating the global UL training updates at the CPU is negligible, and hence ignored.

IV-C The Model of UEâ€™s Energy Consumption

Because the time for UL channel estimation is negligible compared with one FL training interval, the energy consumed in the time block of UL channel estimation is ignored. The energy consumption in the time block of ULTUT at a UE kğ‘˜k is given by

ET,kâ€‹(Î¶k,Ru,k)=Ïuâ€‹N0â€‹Î¶kâ€‹SuRu,k,subscriptğ¸ğ‘‡ğ‘˜subscriptğœğ‘˜subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¢ğ‘˜subscriptğœŒğ‘¢subscriptğ‘0subscriptğœğ‘˜subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¢ğ‘˜\displaystyle E_{T,k}(\zeta_{k},R_{u,k})=\rho_{u}N_{0}\zeta_{k}\frac{S_{u}}{R_{u,k}}, (23)

where Î¶ksubscriptğœğ‘˜\zeta_{k} is the transmitted UL power and SuRu,ksubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¢ğ‘˜\frac{S_{u}}{R_{u,k}} is the delay incurred by transmitting the global UL training update Î”â€‹ğŒkÎ”subscriptğŒğ‘˜\Delta\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\chi}}_{k}. The energy required for computing local training updates at the UE kğ‘˜k is expressed as [10]

EC,kâ€‹(Î¸,fk)=Lâ€‹(Î¸)â€‹Î±2â€‹ckâ€‹Dkâ€‹fk2,subscriptğ¸ğ¶ğ‘˜ğœƒsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ¿ğœƒğ›¼2subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ·ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜2\displaystyle E_{C,k}(\theta,f_{k})=L(\theta)\frac{\alpha}{2}c_{k}D_{k}f_{k}^{2}, (24)

where Î±2ğ›¼2\frac{\alpha}{2} is the effective capacitance coefficient of the UEsâ€™ computing chipset.

V FL Training Time Minimization: Problem Formulation

To optimize the performance of the FL process using the considered FL framework [21] in the CFmMIMO network model discussed in SectionsÂ IV, this paper targets the key performance metric of training time minimization.

In each iteration of the FL process, the time of Step (S1) for a UE kğ‘˜k involves the transmission delay of sending the global DL training update from the CPU to the APs via backhaul links and that from the APs to UE kğ‘˜k via wireless links, i.e.,

tT,kdâ€‹(ğ‘d)=td,Bâ€‹(ğ‘d)+td,kâ€‹(Rd,k)=Kâ€‹Sdâˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦Rd,k+SdRd,k.superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‡ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‘ğµsubscriptğ‘ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘…ğ‘‘ğ‘˜ğ¾subscriptğ‘†ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦subscriptğ‘…ğ‘‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘†ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘…ğ‘‘ğ‘˜\displaystyle t_{T,k}^{d}(\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{d})=t_{d,B}(\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{d})+t_{d,k}(R_{d,k})=\frac{KS_{d}}{\sum_{k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{K}}}R_{d,k}}+\frac{S_{d}}{R_{d,k}}. (25)

Similarly, the time of Step (S2) for the UE kğ‘˜k consists of the delay of transmitting the global UL training update from it to the APs and from the APs to the CPU, i.e.

tT,kuâ€‹(ğ‘u)=tu,kâ€‹(Ru,k)+tu,Bâ€‹(ğ‘u)=SuRu,k+Kâ€‹Suâˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦Ru,k.superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‡ğ‘˜ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘¢ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¢ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘¢ğµsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¢ğ‘˜ğ¾subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¢ğ‘˜\displaystyle t_{T,k}^{u}(\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{u})=t_{u,k}(R_{u,k})+t_{u,B}(\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{u})=\frac{S_{u}}{R_{u,k}}+\frac{KS_{u}}{\sum_{k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{K}}}R_{u,k}}. (26)

In the proposed scheme in SectionÂ II-C, each of the steps (S1)-(S4) of one iteration of the FL process must be completed for all the UEs before the latter step is executed. Therefore, the time of one iteration of the FL process is

The effective time of one FL process is then defined as

Teâ€‹(Î¸,ğŸ,ğ‘d,ğ‘u)subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘’ğœƒğŸsubscriptğ‘ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘¢\displaystyle T_{e}(\theta,\operatorname{\boldsymbol{f}},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{d},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{u}) â‰œGâ€‹(Î¸)â€‹ğ”¼â¡{TGâ€‹(Î¸,ğŸ,ğ‘d,ğ‘u)}â‰œabsentğºğœƒğ”¼subscriptğ‘‡ğºğœƒğŸsubscriptğ‘ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘¢\displaystyle\triangleq G(\theta)\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\{T_{G}(\theta,\operatorname{\boldsymbol{f}},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{d},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{u})\}

For ease of presentation, we make the following definition.

Definition 3.

An effective training time of FL is the effective time of one FL process and is computed as (V).

The problem of FL training time minimization for the FL framework [21] in the considered CFmMIMO system model is thus formulated as:

minğœ¼,ğœ»,Î¸,ğŸ,ğ‘d,ğ‘uğœ¼ğœ»ğœƒğŸsubscriptğ‘ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘¢\displaystyle\underset{\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\eta}},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\zeta}},\theta,\operatorname{\boldsymbol{f}},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{d},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{u}}{\min}\,\, gâ€‹(Î¸,ğŸ,ğ‘d,ğ‘u)â‰œğ”¼â¡{Tâ€‹(Î¸,ğŸ,ğ‘d,ğ‘u)}â‰œğ‘”ğœƒğŸsubscriptğ‘ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘¢ğ”¼ğ‘‡ğœƒğŸsubscriptğ‘ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘¢\displaystyle g(\theta,\operatorname{\boldsymbol{f}},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{d},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{u})\triangleq\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\{T(\theta,\operatorname{\boldsymbol{f}},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{d},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{u})\} (29a)

Here, problem (29) takes into account the issues related to device performance and user experience, i.e., limiting a maximum energy in (29b) and a maximum frequency processing (29c) in order to ensure that performing FL does not affect much on the UEsâ€™ other functions such as data transmission and computation. Problem (29) has a nonconvex stochastic, mixed-timescale structure, along with the tight coupling among the variables. Finding its globally optimal solution is challenging. This paper instead aims to propose a solution approach that is suitable for practical implementation.

Remark 6.

At first glance, the optimization problem (29) is only valid for the FL framework [21] because (8) and (9). Nevertheless, on closer observation, the total training time of any FL process (including [21]) normally involves variables that are optimized in different timescales. The variables such as local accuracy Î¸ğœƒ\theta are optimized in long-term timescales while the variables such as power, rates are optimized in short-term timescales. This leads to the stochastic structure of the training time minimization problems as discussed after (V). In this sense, the optimization problems for other FL frameworks can be different from (35) but their stochastic structures are the same as that of (29). Therefore, we only use the example [21] to show this structure. Moreover, the structure of the algorithms to solve these optimization problems is also the same as that shown in the next section.

VI FL Training Time Minimization: Proposed Algorithm

To resolve problem (29), we utilize the online successive convex approximation approach for solving two-stage stochastic nonconvex optimization problems in [22]. Note that while [22] only provides a general description of the solution method, we specifically tailor it to devise a new algorithm for (29).

According to [31], problem (29) can be decomposed into a family of short-term subproblems and a long-term master problem as follows. For a given Î¸ğœƒ\theta and large-scale fading coefficients ğœ·â‰œ{Î²mâ€‹k}mâˆˆâ„³,kâˆˆğ’¦â‰œğœ·subscriptsubscriptğ›½ğ‘šğ‘˜formulae-sequenceğ‘šâ„³ğ‘˜ğ’¦\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\beta}}\triangleq\{\beta_{mk}\}_{m\in\operatorname{\mathcal{M}},k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{K}}} in each large-scale coherence time, the short-term subproblem is expressed as:

minğœ¼,ğœ»,ğŸ,ğ‘d,ğ‘uğœ¼ğœ»ğŸsubscriptğ‘ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘¢\displaystyle\underset{\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\eta}},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\zeta}},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{f}},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{d},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{u}}{\min}\,\, Tâ€‹(ğŸ,ğ‘d,ğ‘u)ğ‘‡ğŸsubscriptğ‘ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘¢\displaystyle T(\operatorname{\boldsymbol{f}},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{d},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{u}) (30)

By using the variable transformations (33) and (34), it can be seen that the KKT (respectively, FJ) solutions of (35) satisfy the KKT (respectively, FJ) conditions of (32) as well as of (30).

Here, the performance of training update transmission in each iteration of the FL process is enhanced by updating (ğœ¼,ğœ»,ğŸ,ğ‘d,ğ‘u)ğœ¼ğœ»ğŸsubscriptğ‘ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘¢(\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\eta}},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\zeta}},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{f}},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{d},\operatorname{\boldsymbol{R}}_{u}) using AlgorithmÂ 3 in the STO time block. Therefore, AlgorithmÂ 4 is then guaranteed to converge to the neighbourhood of the stationary solutions of problem (29) [22, Theorem 3].

The REPEAT-UNTIL loop runs for Nğ‘N iterations before AlgorithmÂ 4 converges.

VII Cell-Free TDMA Massive MIMO and Collocated Massive MIMO for Wireless Federated Learning

For comparison, this section introduces cell-free TDMA massive MIMO and collocated massive MIMO approaches that support wireless FL. Their associated problem formulations and solution algorithms are discussed in the following.

VII-A Cell-Free TDMA Massive MIMO

The channel estimation of cell-free TDMA massive MIMO networks is equivalent to that of the CFmMIMO networks where all the pilot are pairwisely orthogonal, i.e., ğ‹â„“Hâ¡ğ‹k=0,âˆ€â„“âˆˆğ’¦âˆ–kformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‹â„“ğ»subscriptğ‹ğ‘˜0for-allâ„“ğ’¦ğ‘˜\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\varphi}}_{\ell}^{H}\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\varphi}}_{k}=0,\forall\ell\in\operatorname{\mathcal{K}}\setminus k. While cell-free TDMA massive MIMO networks only require the length of the pilot sequence Ï„~tsubscript~ğœğ‘¡\widetilde{\tau}_{t} to be 111, CFmMIMO networks require Ï„tâ‰¥Ksubscriptğœğ‘¡ğ¾\tau_{t}\geq K for orthogonal pilots with Kğ¾K being the number of UEs.

In cell-free TDMA massive MIMO networks, the training update transmissions between the APs and Kğ¾K UEs happen in Kğ¾K equal orthogonal time slots. Therefore, a factor of (1/K)1ğ¾(1/K) is imposed on the achievable DL and UL rates. Specifically, the achievable DL rate for a UE kğ‘˜k is

where Ïƒmâ€‹k2=Ï„~tâ€‹Ï~tâ€‹(Î²mâ€‹k)2Ï„~tâ€‹Ï~tâ€‹Î²mâ€‹k+1superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘šğ‘˜2subscript~ğœğ‘¡subscript~ğœŒğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ›½ğ‘šğ‘˜2subscript~ğœğ‘¡subscript~ğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğ›½ğ‘šğ‘˜1\sigma_{mk}^{2}=\frac{\widetilde{\tau}_{t}\widetilde{\rho}_{t}(\beta_{mk})^{2}}{\widetilde{\tau}_{t}\widetilde{\rho}_{t}\beta_{mk}+1}, and Ï~tsubscript~ğœŒğ‘¡\widetilde{\rho}_{t} is the normalized signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of each pilot symbol. The achievable UL rate Ru,ksubscriptğ‘…ğ‘¢ğ‘˜R_{u,k} for a UE kğ‘˜k is

(60)

Remark 7.

Our paper does not propose a new FL framework but rather a scheme for a CFmMIMO network to support any FL framework. Here, we consider an existing FL framework [21] as an example to show how to improve the FL performance in terms of training time minimization. Therefore, the simulations on real datasets to see the effectiveness of the considered FL framework has already been performed in [21, Section 6], and hence, they are not considered in this paper. Instead, in what follows, we focus on the numerical results to analyze the effectiveness of the proposed AlgorithmÂ 4 to solve the problem (29) of FL training time minimization for the FL framework [21].

VIII-B Results and Discussions

VIII-B1 Effectiveness of the proposed algorithm

First, we evaluate the convergence behavior of the proposed AlgorithmÂ 4. Fig.Â 4 shows the effective training time Tesubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘’T_{e} versus the number of iterations with D=0.5ğ·0.5D=0.5 km, K=4,Ï„t=10formulae-sequenceğ¾4subscriptğœğ‘¡10K=4,\tau_{t}=10 and M={30,50}ğ‘€3050M=\{30,50\} for an arbitrary large-scale fading realization. It can be seen from Fig.Â 4 that AlgorithmÂ 4 converges in fewer than 100100100 iterations. It is also worth noting that each iteration of AlgorithmÂ 4 corresponds to solving simple convex programs (49) and (57). It is therefore expected that AlgorithmÂ 4 has a low computational complexity.

To further evaluate the effectiveness of AlgorithmÂ 4, we consider the following baseline schemes:

  • â€¢

    Baseline 1 (BL1): The DL powers allocated to all UEs are the same, i.e., Î·mâ€‹kâ€‹Ïƒmâ€‹k2=1/K,âˆ€m,ksubscriptğœ‚ğ‘šğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘šğ‘˜21ğ¾for-allğ‘šğ‘˜\eta_{mk}\sigma_{mk}^{2}=1/K,\forall m,k. The transmitted UL power of each UE is maximum, i.e., Î¶k=1,âˆ€ksubscriptğœğ‘˜1for-allğ‘˜\zeta_{k}=1,\forall k. The local accuracy is fixed, i.e., Î¸=Î¸max+Î¸min2ğœƒsubscriptğœƒsubscriptğœƒ2\theta=\frac{\theta_{\max}+\theta_{\min}}{2} dB. The data rates and processing frequencies of UEs are then optimized.

  • â€¢

    Baseline 2 (BL2): This baseline is similar to BL1 except that Î¸ğœƒ\theta is optimized by a slightly modified version of AlgorithmÂ 4 (without using AlgorithmÂ 3).

  • â€¢

    Baseline 3 (BL3): This baseline is similar to BL1 except that the transmitted DL and UL powers are optimized by AlgorithmÂ 3. Here, the effective training time of FL is the averaged time of one FL process taken over the large-scale fading realizations.

Figs.Â 6 andÂ 6 compare the effective training time Tesubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘’T_{e} by the considered schemes. As seen, AlgorithmÂ 4 gives the best performance. In particular, compared to BL1, the time reduction by AlgorithmÂ 4 is up to 55%percent5555\% with M=50ğ‘€50M=50, K=8ğ¾8K=8. Note that BL2 and BL3 also perform much better than BL1, e.g., up to 29%percent2929\% in term of time reduction with M=50,K=2formulae-sequenceğ‘€50ğ¾2M=50,K=2 and 38%percent3838\% with M=50,K=8formulae-sequenceğ‘€50ğ¾8M=50,K=8, respectively. Even so, AlgorithmÂ 4 still provides substantial time reductions over BL2 and BL3, e.g., up to 49%percent4949\% with M=50,K=8formulae-sequenceğ‘€50ğ¾8M=50,K=8 and 43%percent4343\% with M=90,K=4formulae-sequenceğ‘€90ğ¾4M=90,K=4, respectively.

The figures not only show the importance of optimizing transmit power or local accuracy, but also demonstrate the noticeable advantage of joint optimization design. Moreover, thanks to the array gain, the data rates of UEs increase when the number of APs increases. This leads to the decrease in the effective training time as shown in Fig.Â 6. It can also be observed from Fig.Â 6 that a dramatic increase in the training time when the number of UEs increases. This is because the mutual interference and pilot contamination become stronger for a larger number of UEs.

VIII-B2 Impact of key system parameters on the effective training time

The impact of the local accuracy on the effective training time is shown in Fig.Â 8. Decreasing the threshold Î¸maxsubscriptğœƒ\theta_{\max} leads to a dramatic increase in the effective training time, e.g., by up to 33%percent3333\% with Î¸max=âˆ’40subscriptğœƒ40\theta_{\max}=-40 dB in comparison to that with Î¸max=âˆ’10subscriptğœƒ10\theta_{\max}=-10. This is reasonable because at a lower value of Î¸ğœƒ\theta, more iterations are required for local training. To keep the energy consumption of UEs below Emaxsubscriptğ¸E_{\max}, the UEsâ€™ processing frequencies become smaller. This leads to an increase in the time required to compute the local training updates.

Fig.Â 8 shows the impact of UEâ€™s processing frequency on the effective training time. As seen, the effective training time increases when the threshold fmaxsubscriptğ‘“f_{\max} decreases. In particular, the increase is by up to 19%percent1919\% with fmax=1.5Ã—109subscriptğ‘“1.5superscript109f_{\max}=1.5\times 10^{9} cycles/s in comparison to that with fmax=3Ã—109subscriptğ‘“3superscript109f_{\max}=3\times 10^{9} cycles/s. This is because at a lower value of UEsâ€™ processing frequency, it requires more time to compute the local training updates.

In Fig.Â 10, the impact of UEâ€™s energy consumption limit Emaxsubscriptğ¸E_{\max} on the effective training time is revealed. Here, decreasing Emaxsubscriptğ¸E_{\max} leads to an increase in the effective time. Specifically, the increase is by up to 9.4%percent9.49.4\% with Emax=2subscriptğ¸2E_{\max}=2 J, D=1ğ·1D=1 km in comparison to that with Emax=15subscriptğ¸15E_{\max}=15 J, D=1ğ·1D=1 km. This is reasonable because at a low value of Emaxsubscriptğ¸E_{\max}, the effective time may not approach the optimal value due to a smaller feasible region of the optimization problem (29). We note that in the case of deep fading, the achievable rates of UEs could be small. This may lead to an infeasible problem because the constraint (29b) on the energy consumed at each UE may be violated. However, it should be also emphasized that a cell-free massive MIMO network has many antennas distributed over a potentially large coverage area. As very high small-scale and macro diversity gains can be achieved, the probability of simultaneously experiencing deep fading for all links would be very small. The problem is therefore likely feasible and our proposed solution would apply.

Fig.Â 10 focuses on the impact of the length of UL pilots on the effective training time. It is clear that too small and too large values of Ï„tsubscriptğœğ‘¡\tau_{t} both increase the effective time. Specially, the effective time increases up to 10%percent1010\% and 1%percent11\% with Ï„t=1subscriptğœğ‘¡1\tau_{t}=1 and Ï„t=13subscriptğœğ‘¡13\tau_{t}=13 in comparison to that with Ï„t=7subscriptğœğ‘¡7\tau_{t}=7, respectively. This is reasonable because at a large value of Ï„tsubscriptğœğ‘¡\tau_{t}, the factor of Tcâˆ’Ï„tTcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘subscriptğœğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\frac{T_{c}-\tau_{t}}{T_{c}} makes the data rate decrease and the transmission time grows. In contrast, at a small value of Ï„tsubscriptğœğ‘¡\tau_{t}, the network suffers more from the pilot contamination, the data rates drop and the training update transmission time increases.

VIII-B3 Cell-free massive MIMO vs. Cell-free TDMA massive MIMO

Fig.Â 12 compares the cell-free massive MIMO system with the cell-free TDMA massive MIMO system. Since the pilot sequences of UEs in the latter are pairwisely orthogonal in the time domain, we choose orthogonal pilot sequences for the former, i.e., ğ‹â„“Hâ¡ğ‹k=0,âˆ€â„“âˆˆğ’¦âˆ–kformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‹â„“ğ»subscriptğ‹ğ‘˜0for-allâ„“ğ’¦ğ‘˜\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\varphi}}_{\ell}^{H}\operatorname{\boldsymbol{\varphi}}_{k}=0,\forall\ell\in\operatorname{\mathcal{K}}\setminus k, for a fair comparison. The training durations are then the same for both systems. We also choose Ï~t=Kâ€‹Ïtsubscript~ğœŒğ‘¡ğ¾subscriptğœŒğ‘¡\widetilde{\rho}_{t}=K\rho_{t} for the amount of energy consumed at the â€œUL channel estimationâ€ time blocks of the two networks to be the same, and Ï„t=Ksubscriptğœğ‘¡ğ¾\tau_{t}=K so that the powers of channel estimate, i.e., Ïƒmâ€‹k2,âˆ€m,ksuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘šğ‘˜2for-allğ‘šğ‘˜\sigma_{mk}^{2},\forall m,k, are the same in the two networks. From Fig.Â 12, a significant time reduction (e.g., of up to 94%percent9494\% with K=8ğ¾8K=8) is achieved by the CFmMIMO compared with the cell-free TDMA massive MIMO. This result is expected because in the former, the factor of (1/K)1ğ¾(1/K) is imposed on the data rates and the training updates are transmitted sequentially. For a large number of UEs, the data rate is significantly small, and as a result, the training update transmission requires a substantially long time.

VIII-B4 Cell-free massive MIMO vs. Collocated massive MIMO

Finally, we compare the effective training time in CFmMIMO with that in collocated massive MIMO. Fig.Â 12 shows that the former significantly outperform the latter, e.g., the time reduction is by up to 57%percent5757\% with M=30ğ‘€30M=30 and D=1ğ·1D=1 km. This observation is as expected because CFmMIMO distributes antennas over their coverage area; and as such, their performance suffers less from the UEs with unfavorable links than that of collocated massive MIMO. Higher data rates and a lower training time then follow.

IX Conclusion

In this paper, we have proposed using CFmMIMO networks to support FL in a wireless environment. We designed a general scheme in which any algorithm and beamforming/filtering approach can be further developed to optimize the performance of any FL framework. Specially here, each iteration of the FL optimization algorithms or the FL process happens in one large-scale coherence time. Targeting training time minimization for the FL framework [21] as example, we jointly design local accuracy, transmit power, data rate, and UEâ€™s processing frequency under the practical requirements on the UEâ€™s energy consumption limit and maximum transmit powers at the APs and UEs. A mixed timescale stochastic nonconvex optimization problem has been formulated with the objective of minimizing the training time of one FL process. Based on the general online successive convex approximation framework, we have developed a new algorithm to successfully solve the formulated problem. We have proved that the proposed algorithm converges to the neighborhood of stationary points of the optimization problem. For given parameter settings, numerical results show that our joint optimization design significantly reduces the training time of FL over the baselines under comparison. They have also confirmed that CFmMIMO offers the lowest training time when compared with cell-free TDMA massive MIMO and collocated massive MIMO.
